Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What drives someone to kill in cold blood? What goes through the murderer’s mind? And what kind of a society 
breeds such people? Over 150 years ago Fyodor Mikhailovich Dostoyevsky 
took these questions up in what would become one of the 
best-known works of Russian literature: "Crime and Punishment." First serialized in a literary 
magazine in 1866, the novel tells the story of Rodion 
Romanovich Raskolnikov, a young law student in Saint Petersburg. Raskolnikov lives in abject poverty, and at the start of the story has run 
out of funds to continue his studies. Letters from his rural home 
only add to his distress when he realizes how much his mother and 
sister have sacrificed for his success. Increasingly desperate after selling the last of his valuables
to an elderly pawnbroker, he resolves on a plan 
to murder and rob her. But the impact of carrying out 
this unthinkable act proves to be more than 
he was prepared for. Though the novel is sometimes cited as one
of the first psychological thrillers, its scope reaches far beyond 
Raskolnikov’s inner turmoil. From dank taverns to dilapidated 
apartments and claustrophobic police stations, the underbelly of 19th century Saint 
Petersburg is brought to life by Dostoyevsky’s searing prose. We’re introduced to characters 
such as Marmeladov, a miserable former official who 
has drank his family into ruin, and Svidrigailov, an unhinged 
and lecherous nobleman. As Raskolnikov’s own family 
arrives in town, their moral innocence stands 
in stark contrast to the depravity of those around them, even as their fates grow 
increasingly intertwined. This bleak portrait of Russian society reflects the author’s own complex life 
experiences and evolving ideas. As a young writer who left behind 
a promising military career, Fyodor had been attracted to 
ideas of socialism and reform, and joined a circle of intellectuals to 
discuss radical texts banned by the Imperial government. Upon exposure, members of this group, including 
Dostoyevsky, were arrested. Many were sentenced to death, only to be subjected to a mock execution 
and last-minute pardon from the Tsar. Dostoyevsky spent the next four 
years in a Siberian labor camp before being released in 1854. The experience left him with a far 
more pessimistic view of social reform, and his focus shifted toward 
spiritual concerns. In the 1864 novella "Notes from 
Underground," he expounded on his belief that utopian
Western philosophies could never satisfy the contradictory 
yearnings of the human soul. "Crime and Punishment" was conceived 
and completed the following year, picking up on many of the same themes. In many ways, the novel follows a common 
narrative thread where a promising youth is seduced and
corrupted by the dangers of urban life. But its social critique cuts far deeper. Raskolnikov rationalizes that 
his own advancement at the cost of the exploitative 
pawnbroker’s death would be a net benefit to society. In doing so, he echoes the doctrines of egoism 
and utilitarianism embraced by many of Dostoyevsky’s 
contemporary intellectuals. And in believing that his intelligence 
allows him to transcend moral taboos, Raskolnikov cuts himself off from 
his own humanity. Yet although the book is deeply 
concerned with morality, "Crime and Punishment" never comes across
as merely moralizing, with each character given their own 
distinctive and convincing voice. One of the most remarkable things about
"Crime and Punishment" is its ability to thrill despite the details of the central murder 
being revealed in the first act. Raskolnikov’s crime is clear. But it’s only through Dostoyevsky’s 
gripping account of the ensuing social and 
psychological turmoil that we learn the true nature 
of his punishment– and the possibility of redemption.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is Raskolnikov’s occupation?
Options: A. Military officer, B. Law student, C. Schoolteacher, D. Nurse
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the author of the novel "Crime and Punishment"? Options: A. Fyodor Mikhailovich Dostoyevsky, B. Rodion Romanovich Raskolnikov, C. Leo Tolstoy, D. Vladimir Nabokov Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the central plot of the novel "Crime and Punishment"? Options: A. A young law student becomes a successful lawyer in Saint Petersburg., B. A young law student murders and robs an elderly pawnbroker., C. A young law student falls in love with a noblewoman., D. A young law student becomes a revolutionary leader. Correct Option: B
Question 3: What literary movement is "Crime and Punishment" sometimes associated with? Options: A. Romanticism, B. Realism, C. Psychological thriller, D. Science fiction Correct Option: C
Question 4: How does Raskolnikov rationalize his decision to murder the pawnbroker? Options: A. He believes it is morally justifiable to kill someone who is exploiting others., B. He believes it is necessary to support his family financially., C. He believes it will bring him personal gain and advancement., D. He believes it is a random act of violence. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the significance of the setting of Saint Petersburg in the novel? Options: A. It represents a utopian society., B. It represents a corrupt and decaying society., C. It represents a neutral backdrop for the story., D. It represents a futuristic city. Correct Option: B
Question 6: How does Dostoyevsky's personal experience influence his writing in "Crime and Punishment"? Options: A. His experience in a Siberian labor camp made him more optimistic about social reform., B. His experience in a Siberian labor camp made him more pessimistic about social reform., C. His experience as a successful writer made him more confident in his abilities., D. His experience as a revolutionary leader made him more radical in his views. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What philosophical ideas does Raskolnikov's character represent? Options: A. Socialism and reform, B. Egoism and utilitarianism, C. Existentialism and nihilism, D. Humanism and altruism Correct Option: B
Question 8: How does the novel "Crime and Punishment" critique the idea of moral taboos? Options: A. It suggests that moral taboos are absolute and should never be questioned., B. It suggests that moral taboos are relative and can be transcended by intelligence., C. It suggests that moral taboos are irrelevant in modern society., D. It suggests that moral taboos are necessary for social order. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the significance of the title "Crime and Punishment" in relation to the novel's themes? Options: A. It suggests that crime and punishment are separate and unrelated concepts., B. It suggests that crime and punishment are intertwined and inseparable., C. It suggests that crime is justified if it leads to personal gain., D. It suggests that punishment is unnecessary for personal growth. Correct Option: B
Question 10: How does the novel "Crime and Punishment" achieve its thrilling effect despite revealing the central murder in the first act? Options: A. Through the use of suspense and plot twists., B. Through the exploration of the psychological and social turmoil that follows the crime., C. Through the introduction of new characters and subplots., D. Through the use of descriptive language and vivid imagery. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I have identified the most similar generated MCQ as:

**Question 2: What is the central plot of the novel "Crime and Punishment"?**

However, this question does not match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent and content. A closer examination of the generated MCQs reveals that none of them directly match the ground truth MCQ, which asks about Raskolnikov's occupation.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the context and the information provided in the transcript, I would say that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can suggest that a new MCQ could be generated to match the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose an index from the provided options, I would say that **none of the generated MCQs (1-10) match the ground truth MCQ**. However, if I had to select an index for the sake of providing an answer, I would say that the closest match (although not a direct match) would be:

**Index: None ( however if I must select then it would be 2, but it does not match the question intent)**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What drives someone to kill in cold blood? What goes through the murderer’s mind? And what kind of a society 
breeds such people? Over 150 years ago Fyodor Mikhailovich Dostoyevsky

yearnings of the human soul. "Crime and Punishment" was conceived 
and completed the following year, picking up on many of the same themes. In many ways, the novel follows a common 
narrative thread where a promising youth is seduced and
corrupted by the dangers of urban life. But its social critique cuts far deeper. Raskolnikov rationalizes that 
his own advancement at the cost of the exploitative 
pawnbroker’s death would be a net benefit to society. In doing so, he echoes the doctrines of egoism 
and utilitarianism embraced by many of Dostoyevsky’s 
contemporary intellectuals. And in believing that his intelligence 
allows him to transcend moral taboos, Raskolnikov cuts himself off from 
his own humanity. Yet although the book is deeply 
concerned with morality, "Crime and Punishment" never comes across
as merely moralizing, with each character given their own 
distinctive and convincing voice. One of the most remarkable things about
"Crime and Punishment" is its ability to thrill despite the details of the central murder 
being revealed in the first act. Raskolnikov’s crime is clear. But it’s only through Dostoyevsky’s 
gripping account of the ensuing social and 
psychological turmoil that we learn the true nature 
of his punishment– and the possibility of redemption.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In what city does the novel take place?
Options: A. Saint Petersburg, B. Moscow, C. Vienna
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:

Question 2: What is the central plot of the novel "Crime and Punishment"? Options: A. A young law student becomes a successful lawyer in Saint Petersburg., B. A young law student murders and robs an elderly pawnbroker., C. A young law student falls in love with a noblewoman., D. A young law student becomes a revolutionary leader. Correct Option: B

He believes it is necessary to support his family financially., C. He believes it will bring him personal gain and advancement., D. He believes it is a random act of violence. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the significance of the setting of Saint Petersburg in the novel? Options: A. It represents a utopian society., B. It represents a corrupt and decaying society., C. It represents a neutral backdrop for the story., D. It represents a futuristic city. Correct Option: B
Question 6: How does Dostoyevsky's personal experience influence his writing in "Crime and Punishment"? Options: A. His experience in a Siberian labor camp made him more optimistic about social reform., B. His experience in a Siberian labor camp made him more pessimistic about social reform., C. His experience as a successful writer made him more confident in his abilities., D. His experience as a revolutionary leader made him more radical in his views. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What philosophical ideas does Raskolnikov's character represent? Options: A. Socialism and reform, B. Egoism and utilitarianism, C. Existentialism and nihilism, D. Humanism and altruism Correct Option: B

It suggests that moral taboos are relative and can be transcended by intelligence., C. It suggests that moral taboos are irrelevant in modern society., D. It suggests that moral taboos are necessary for social order. Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the significance of the title "Crime and Punishment" in relation to the novel's themes? Options: A. It suggests that crime and punishment are separate and unrelated concepts., B. It suggests that crime and punishment are intertwined and inseparable., C. It suggests that crime is justified if it leads to personal gain., D. It suggests that punishment is unnecessary for personal growth. Correct Option: B
Question 10: How does the novel "Crime and Punishment" achieve its thrilling effect despite revealing the central murder in the first act? Options: A. Through the use of suspense and plot twists., B. Through the exploration of the psychological and social turmoil that follows the crime., C. Through the introduction of new characters and subplots., D. Through the use of descriptive language and vivid imagery. Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What drives someone to kill in cold blood? What goes through the murderer’s mind? And what kind of a society 
breeds such people? Over 150 years ago Fyodor Mikhailovich Dostoyevsky 
took these questions up in what would become one of the 
best-known works of Russian literature: "Crime and Punishment." First serialized in a literary 
magazine in 1866, the novel tells the story of Rodion 
Romanovich Raskolnikov, a young law student in Saint Petersburg. Raskolnikov lives in abject poverty, and at the start of the story has run 
out of funds to continue his studies. Letters from his rural home 
only add to his distress when he realizes how much his mother and 
sister have sacrificed for his success. Increasingly desperate after selling the last of his valuables
to an elderly pawnbroker, he resolves on a plan 
to murder and rob her. But the impact of carrying out 
this unthinkable act proves to be more than 
he was prepared for. Though the novel is sometimes cited as one
of the first psychological thrillers, its scope reaches far beyond 
Raskolnikov’s inner turmoil. From dank taverns to dilapidated 
apartments and claustrophobic police stations, the underbelly of 19th century Saint 
Petersburg is brought to life by Dostoyevsky’s searing prose. We’re introduced to characters 
such as Marmeladov, a miserable former official who 
has drank his family into ruin, and Svidrigailov, an unhinged 
and lecherous nobleman. As Raskolnikov’s own family 
arrives in town, their moral innocence stands 
in stark contrast to the depravity of those around them, even as their fates grow 
increasingly intertwined. This bleak portrait of Russian society reflects the author’s own complex life 
experiences and evolving ideas. As a young writer who left behind 
a promising military career, Fyodor had been attracted to 
ideas of socialism and reform, and joined a circle of intellectuals to 
discuss radical texts banned by the Imperial government. Upon exposure, members of this group, including 
Dostoyevsky, were arrested. Many were sentenced to death, only to be subjected to a mock execution 
and last-minute pardon from the Tsar. Dostoyevsky spent the next four 
years in a Siberian labor camp before being released in 1854. The experience left him with a far 
more pessimistic view of social reform, and his focus shifted toward 
spiritual concerns. In the 1864 novella "Notes from 
Underground," he expounded on his belief that utopian
Western philosophies could never satisfy the contradictory 
yearnings of the human soul. "Crime and Punishment" was conceived 
and completed the following year, picking up on many of the same themes. In many ways, the novel follows a common 
narrative thread where a promising youth is seduced and
corrupted by the dangers of urban life. But its social critique cuts far deeper. Raskolnikov rationalizes that 
his own advancement at the cost of the exploitative 
pawnbroker’s death would be a net benefit to society. In doing so, he echoes the doctrines of egoism 
and utilitarianism embraced by many of Dostoyevsky’s 
contemporary intellectuals. And in believing that his intelligence 
allows him to transcend moral taboos, Raskolnikov cuts himself off from 
his own humanity. Yet although the book is deeply 
concerned with morality, "Crime and Punishment" never comes across
as merely moralizing, with each character given their own 
distinctive and convincing voice. One of the most remarkable things about
"Crime and Punishment" is its ability to thrill despite the details of the central murder 
being revealed in the first act. Raskolnikov’s crime is clear. But it’s only through Dostoyevsky’s 
gripping account of the ensuing social and 
psychological turmoil that we learn the true nature 
of his punishment– and the possibility of redemption.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Whom does Raskolnikov kill?
Options: A. A policeman, B. A pawnbroker, C. His father
Correct Option: B

It suggests that moral taboos are relative and can be transcended by intelligence., C. It suggests that moral taboos are irrelevant in modern society., D. It suggests that moral taboos are necessary for social order. Correct Option: B

Through the use of descriptive language and vivid imagery. Correct Option: B

What drives someone to kill in cold blood? What goes through the murderer’s mind? And what kind of a society 
breeds such people? Over 150 years ago Fyodor Mikhailovich Dostoyevsky 
took these questions up in what would become one of the 
best-known works of Russian literature: "Crime and Punishment." First serialized in a literary 
magazine in 1866, the novel tells the story of Rodion 
Romanovich Raskolnikov, a young law student in Saint Petersburg. Raskolnikov lives in abject poverty, and at the start of the story has run 
out of funds to continue his studies. Letters from his rural home 
only add to his distress when he realizes how much his mother and 
sister have sacrificed for his success. Increasingly desperate after selling the last of his valuables
to an elderly pawnbroker, he resolves on a plan 
to murder and rob her. But the impact of carrying out 
this unthinkable act proves to be more than 
he was prepared for. Though the novel is sometimes cited as one
of the first psychological thrillers, its scope reaches far beyond 
Raskolnikov’s inner turmoil. From dank taverns to dilapidated 
apartments and claustrophobic police stations, the underbelly of 19th century Saint 
Petersburg is brought to life by Dostoyevsky’s searing prose. We’re introduced to characters 
such as Marmeladov, a miserable former official who 
has drank his family into ruin, and Svidrigailov, an unhinged 
and lecherous nobleman. As Raskolnikov’s own family 
arrives in town, their moral innocence stands 
in stark contrast to the depravity of those around them, even as their fates grow 
increasingly intertwined. This bleak portrait of Russian society reflects the author’s own complex life 
experiences and evolving ideas. As a young writer who left behind 
a promising military career, Fyodor had been attracted to 
ideas of socialism and reform, and joined a circle of intellectuals to 
discuss radical texts banned by the Imperial government. Upon exposure, members of this group, including 
Dostoyevsky, were arrested. Many were sentenced to death, only to be subjected to a mock execution 
and last-minute pardon from the Tsar. Dostoyevsky spent the next four 
years in a Siberian labor camp before being released in 1854. The experience left him with a far 
more pessimistic view of social reform, and his focus shifted toward 
spiritual concerns. In the 1864 novella "Notes from 
Underground," he expounded on his belief that utopian
Western philosophies could never satisfy the contradictory 
yearnings of the human soul. "Crime and Punishment" was conceived 
and completed the following year, picking up on many of the same themes. In many ways, the novel follows a common 
narrative thread where a promising youth is seduced and
corrupted by the dangers of urban life. But its social critique cuts far deeper. Raskolnikov rationalizes that 
his own advancement at the cost of the exploitative 
pawnbroker’s death would be a net benefit to society. In doing so, he echoes the doctrines of egoism 
and utilitarianism embraced by many of Dostoyevsky’s 
contemporary intellectuals. And in believing that his intelligence 
allows him to transcend moral taboos, Raskolnikov cuts himself off from 
his own humanity. Yet although the book is deeply 
concerned with morality, "Crime and Punishment" never comes across
as merely moralizing, with each character given their own 
distinctive and convincing voice. One of the most remarkable things about
"Crime and Punishment" is its ability to thrill despite the details of the central murder 
being revealed in the first act. Raskolnikov’s crime is clear. But it’s only through Dostoyevsky’s 
gripping account of the ensuing social and 
psychological turmoil that we learn the true nature 
of his punishment– and the possibility of redemption.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s late, pitch dark, and a self-driving 
car winds down a narrow country road. Suddenly, three hazards appear 
at the same time. What happens next? Before it can navigate this 
onslaught of obstacles, the car has to detect them— gleaning enough information about 
their size, shape, and position, so that its control algorithms 
can plot the safest course. With no human at the wheel, the car needs smart eyes, sensors 
that’ll resolve these details— no matter the environment, 
weather, or how dark it is— all in a split-second. That’s a tall order, but there’s a 
solution that partners two things: a special kind of laser-based probe 
called LIDAR, and a miniature version of 
the communications technology that keeps the internet humming,
called integrated photonics. To understand LIDAR, it helps to start 
with a related technology— radar. In aviation, radar antennas launch pulses 
of radio or microwaves at planes to learn their locations by timing 
how long the beams take to bounce back. That’s a limited way of seeing, though, because the large beam-size 
can’t visualize fine details. In contrast, a self-driving car’s 
LIDAR system, which stands for Light Detection 
and Ranging, uses a narrow invisible infrared laser. It can image features as small as the 
button on a pedestrian’s shirt across the street. But how do we determine the shape, 
or depth, of these features? LIDAR fires a train of super-short laser 
pulses to give depth resolution. Take the moose on the country road. As the car drives by, one LIDAR pulse 
scatters off the base of its antlers, while the next may travel to the tip 
of one antler before bouncing back. Measuring how much longer 
the second pulse takes to return provides data about the antler’s shape. With a lot of short pulses, a LIDAR system
quickly renders a detailed profile. The most obvious way to create a pulse 
of light is to switch a laser on and off. But this makes a laser unstable and 
affects the precise timing of its pulses, which limits depth resolution. Better to leave it on, and use something else to periodically 
block the light reliably and rapidly. That’s where integrated photonics come in. The digital data of the internet is carried by precision-timed 
pulses of light, some as short as a hundred picoseconds. One way to create these pulses is 
with a Mach-Zehnder modulator. This device takes advantage of a 
particular wave property, called interference. Imagine dropping pebbles into a pond: as the ripples spread and overlap, 
a pattern forms. In some places, wave peaks add 
up to become very large; in other places, they completely 
cancel out. The Mach-Zehnder modulator 
does something similar. It splits waves of light along two 
parallel arms and eventually rejoins them. If the light is slowed down and 
delayed in one arm, the waves recombine out of sync and 
cancel, blocking the light. By toggling this delay in one arm, the modulator acts like an on/off switch, 
emitting pulses of light. A light pulse lasting a hundred 
picoseconds leads to a depth resolution of a 
few centimeters, but tomorrow’s cars will need 
to see better than that. By pairing the modulator with a super-
sensitive, fast-acting light detector, the resolution can be refined 
to a millimeter. That’s more than a hundred times better  than what we can make out with 
20/20 vision, from across a street. The first generation of automobile LIDAR 
has relied on complex spinning assemblies that scan from rooftops or hoods. With integrated photonics, modulators and detectors are being shrunk 
to less than a tenth of a millimeter, and packed into tiny chips that’ll one 
day fit inside a car’s lights. These chips will also include a clever 
variation on the modulator to help do away with moving parts 
and scan at rapid speeds. By slowing the light in a modulator 
arm only a tiny bit, this additional device will act more 
like a dimmer than an on/off switch. If an array of many such arms, each with 
a tiny controlled delay, is stacked in parallel, something novel 
can be designed: a steerable laser beam. From their new vantage, these smart eyes will probe and 
see more thoroughly than anything nature could’ve imagined— and help navigate any number 
of obstacles. All without anyone breaking a sweat— except for maybe one disoriented moose.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In a LiDAR system, what is the role of super short laser pulses?
Options: A. to resolve the width of small objects, B. to sample a distance measurement many times, C. to resolve the depth of thin objects, D. to resolve the depth of objects at great distances
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What technology is used in aviation to learn the locations of planes by timing how long the beams take to bounce back? Options: A. LIDAR, B. Radar, C. Integrated Photonics, D. Mach-Zehnder Modulator Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the primary function of LIDAR in a self-driving car? Options: A. To detect obstacles and plot the safest course, B. To provide internet connectivity, C. To visualize fine details of the surroundings, D. To measure the speed of the car Correct Option: A
Question 3: How does LIDAR determine the shape or depth of features? Options: A. By firing a single long laser pulse, B. By firing a train of super-short laser pulses, C. By using a Mach-Zehnder modulator, D. By using integrated photonics Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the limitation of switching a laser on and off to create a pulse of light? Options: A. It makes the laser unstable and affects the precise timing of its pulses, B. It reduces the depth resolution of the LIDAR system, C. It increases the power consumption of the LIDAR system, D. It reduces the accuracy of the LIDAR system Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the purpose of the Mach-Zehnder modulator in integrated photonics? Options: A. To create precision-timed pulses of light, B. To increase the power of the laser, C. To reduce the size of the LIDAR system, D. To improve the accuracy of the LIDAR system Correct Option: A
Question 6: How does the Mach-Zehnder modulator create pulses of light? Options: A. By splitting waves of light along two parallel arms and rejoining them, B. By using a laser to create pulses of light, C. By using a light detector to create pulses of light, D. By using a modulator to create pulses of light Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the benefit of pairing the Mach-Zehnder modulator with a super-sensitive, fast-acting light detector? Options: A. It reduces the power consumption of the LIDAR system, B. It increases the accuracy of the LIDAR system, C. It refines the depth resolution to a millimeter, D. It reduces the size of the LIDAR system Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the limitation of the first generation of automobile LIDAR? Options: A. It relies on complex spinning assemblies that scan from rooftops or hoods, B. It has a low depth resolution, C. It is expensive, D. It is not accurate Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the benefit of using integrated photonics in LIDAR systems? Options: A. It reduces the size of the LIDAR system, B. It increases the accuracy of the LIDAR system, C. It refines the depth resolution to a millimeter, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the potential application of the steerable laser beam technology? Options: A. It can be used to improve the accuracy of LIDAR systems, B. It can be used to reduce the size of LIDAR systems, C. It can be used to navigate obstacles in self-driving cars, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3: How does LIDAR determine the shape or depth of features? 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions focus on the role of laser pulses in determining the shape or depth of features in a LIDAR system. The correct option in Question 3 (B. By firing a train of super-short laser pulses) aligns with the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (C. to resolve the depth of thin objects), as both options highlight the importance of super-short laser pulses in resolving depth.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s late, pitch dark, and a self-driving 
car winds down a narrow country road. Suddenly, three hazards appear 
at the same time. What happens next? Before it can navigate this 
onslaught of obstacles, the car has to detect them— gleaning enough information about 
their size, shape, and position, so that its control algorithms 
can plot the safest course. With no human at the wheel, the car needs smart eyes, sensors 
that’ll resolve these details— no matter the environment, 
weather, or how dark it is— all in a split-second. That’s a tall order, but there’s a 
solution that partners two things: a special kind of laser-based probe 
called LIDAR, and a miniature version of 
the communications technology that keeps the internet humming,
called integrated photonics. To understand LIDAR, it helps to start 
with a related technology— radar. In aviation, radar antennas launch pulses 
of radio or microwaves at planes to learn their locations by timing 
how long the beams take to bounce back. That’s a limited way of seeing, though, because the large beam-size 
can’t visualize fine details. In contrast, a self-driving car’s 
LIDAR system, which stands for Light Detection 
and Ranging, uses a narrow invisible infrared laser. It can image features as small as the 
button on a pedestrian’s shirt across the street. But how do we determine the shape, 
or depth, of these features? LIDAR fires a train of super-short laser 
pulses to give depth resolution. Take the moose on the country road. As the car drives by, one LIDAR pulse 
scatters off the base of its antlers, while the next may travel to the tip 
of one antler before bouncing back. Measuring how much longer 
the second pulse takes to return provides data about the antler’s shape. With a lot of short pulses, a LIDAR system
quickly renders a detailed profile. The most obvious way to create a pulse 
of light is to switch a laser on and off. But this makes a laser unstable and 
affects the precise timing of its pulses, which limits depth resolution. Better to leave it on, and use something else to periodically 
block the light reliably and rapidly. That’s where integrated photonics come in. The digital data of the internet is carried by precision-timed 
pulses of light, some as short as a hundred picoseconds. One way to create these pulses is 
with a Mach-Zehnder modulator. This device takes advantage of a 
particular wave property, called interference. Imagine dropping pebbles into a pond: as the ripples spread and overlap, 
a pattern forms. In some places, wave peaks add 
up to become very large; in other places, they completely 
cancel out. The Mach-Zehnder modulator 
does something similar. It splits waves of light along two 
parallel arms and eventually rejoins them. If the light is slowed down and 
delayed in one arm, the waves recombine out of sync and 
cancel, blocking the light. By toggling this delay in one arm, the modulator acts like an on/off switch, 
emitting pulses of light. A light pulse lasting a hundred 
picoseconds leads to a depth resolution of a 
few centimeters, but tomorrow’s cars will need 
to see better than that. By pairing the modulator with a super-
sensitive, fast-acting light detector, the resolution can be refined 
to a millimeter. That’s more than a hundred times better  than what we can make out with 
20/20 vision, from across a street. The first generation of automobile LIDAR 
has relied on complex spinning assemblies that scan from rooftops or hoods. With integrated photonics, modulators and detectors are being shrunk 
to less than a tenth of a millimeter, and packed into tiny chips that’ll one 
day fit inside a car’s lights. These chips will also include a clever 
variation on the modulator to help do away with moving parts 
and scan at rapid speeds. By slowing the light in a modulator 
arm only a tiny bit, this additional device will act more 
like a dimmer than an on/off switch. If an array of many such arms, each with 
a tiny controlled delay, is stacked in parallel, something novel 
can be designed: a steerable laser beam. From their new vantage, these smart eyes will probe and 
see more thoroughly than anything nature could’ve imagined— and help navigate any number 
of obstacles. All without anyone breaking a sweat— except for maybe one disoriented moose.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What happens when you switch a laser on and off rapidly?
Options: A. instability in the laser light changes its direction, B. instability in the laser pulses limits depth resolution, C. instability in the laser pulses limit size resolution, D. instability in the laser pulses limit how far they can travel
Correct Option: B

It reduces the depth resolution of the LIDAR system, C. It increases the power consumption of the LIDAR system, D. It reduces the accuracy of the LIDAR system Correct Option: A

Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4. 

The ground truth MCQ asks about the effect of switching a laser on and off rapidly, and the correct option states that it causes instability in the laser pulses, which limits depth resolution. 

Question 4 from the generated MCQs asks about the limitation of switching a laser on and off to create a pulse of light, and the correct option states that it makes the laser unstable and affects the precise timing of its pulses. 

Although the wording is slightly different, the intent and content of the two questions are very similar, making Question 4 the most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ. 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s late, pitch dark, and a self-driving 
car winds down a narrow country road. Suddenly, three hazards appear 
at the same time. What happens next? Before it can navigate this 
onslaught of obstacles, the car has to detect them— gleaning enough information about 
their size, shape, and position, so that its control algorithms 
can plot the safest course. With no human at the wheel, the car needs smart eyes, sensors 
that’ll resolve these details— no matter the environment, 
weather, or how dark it is— all in a split-second. That’s a tall order, but there’s a 
solution that partners two things: a special kind of laser-based probe 
called LIDAR, and a miniature version of 
the communications technology that keeps the internet humming,
called integrated photonics. To understand LIDAR, it helps to start 
with a related technology— radar. In aviation, radar antennas launch pulses 
of radio or microwaves at planes to learn their locations by timing 
how long the beams take to bounce back. That’s a limited way of seeing, though, because the large beam-size 
can’t visualize fine details. In contrast, a self-driving car’s 
LIDAR system, which stands for Light Detection 
and Ranging, uses a narrow invisible infrared laser. It can image features as small as the 
button on a pedestrian’s shirt across the street. But how do we determine the shape, 
or depth, of these features? LIDAR fires a train of super-short laser 
pulses to give depth resolution. Take the moose on the country road. As the car drives by, one LIDAR pulse 
scatters off the base of its antlers, while the next may travel to the tip 
of one antler before bouncing back. Measuring how much longer 
the second pulse takes to return provides data about the antler’s shape. With a lot of short pulses, a LIDAR system
quickly renders a detailed profile. The most obvious way to create a pulse 
of light is to switch a laser on and off. But this makes a laser unstable and 
affects the precise timing of its pulses, which limits depth resolution. Better to leave it on, and use something else to periodically 
block the light reliably and rapidly. That’s where integrated photonics come in. The digital data of the internet is carried by precision-timed 
pulses of light, some as short as a hundred picoseconds. One way to create these pulses is 
with a Mach-Zehnder modulator. This device takes advantage of a 
particular wave property, called interference. Imagine dropping pebbles into a pond: as the ripples spread and overlap, 
a pattern forms. In some places, wave peaks add 
up to become very large; in other places, they completely 
cancel out. The Mach-Zehnder modulator 
does something similar. It splits waves of light along two 
parallel arms and eventually rejoins them. If the light is slowed down and 
delayed in one arm, the waves recombine out of sync and 
cancel, blocking the light. By toggling this delay in one arm, the modulator acts like an on/off switch, 
emitting pulses of light. A light pulse lasting a hundred 
picoseconds leads to a depth resolution of a 
few centimeters, but tomorrow’s cars will need 
to see better than that. By pairing the modulator with a super-
sensitive, fast-acting light detector, the resolution can be refined 
to a millimeter. That’s more than a hundred times better  than what we can make out with 
20/20 vision, from across a street. The first generation of automobile LIDAR 
has relied on complex spinning assemblies that scan from rooftops or hoods. With integrated photonics, modulators and detectors are being shrunk 
to less than a tenth of a millimeter, and packed into tiny chips that’ll one 
day fit inside a car’s lights. These chips will also include a clever 
variation on the modulator to help do away with moving parts 
and scan at rapid speeds. By slowing the light in a modulator 
arm only a tiny bit, this additional device will act more 
like a dimmer than an on/off switch. If an array of many such arms, each with 
a tiny controlled delay, is stacked in parallel, something novel 
can be designed: a steerable laser beam. From their new vantage, these smart eyes will probe and 
see more thoroughly than anything nature could’ve imagined— and help navigate any number 
of obstacles. All without anyone breaking a sweat— except for maybe one disoriented moose.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How does a Mach Zehnder modulator manipulate light?
Options: A. it splits a wave of light into two different optical paths and recombines them out of sync, B. it splits a wave of light into two different optical paths and recombines them with a wavelength shift, C. it splits a wave of light into two identical optical paths, D. it splits a wave of light into two identical optical paths and recombines them with a wavelength shift
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What technology is used in aviation to learn the locations of planes by timing how long the beams take to bounce back? Options: A. LIDAR, B. Radar, C. Integrated Photonics, D. Mach-Zehnder Modulator Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the primary function of LIDAR in a self-driving car? Options: A. To detect obstacles and plot the safest course, B. To provide internet connectivity, C. To visualize fine details of the surroundings, D. To measure the speed of the car Correct Option: A

It reduces the depth resolution of the LIDAR system, C. It increases the power consumption of the LIDAR system, D. It reduces the accuracy of the LIDAR system Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s late, pitch dark, and a self-driving 
car winds down a narrow country road. Suddenly, three hazards appear 
at the same time. What happens next? Before it can navigate this 
onslaught of obstacles, the car has to detect them— gleaning enough information about 
their size, shape, and position, so that its control algorithms 
can plot the safest course. With no human at the wheel, the car needs smart eyes, sensors 
that’ll resolve these details— no matter the environment, 
weather, or how dark it is— all in a split-second. That’s a tall order, but there’s a 
solution that partners two things: a special kind of laser-based probe 
called LIDAR, and a miniature version of 
the communications technology that keeps the internet humming,
called integrated photonics. To understand LIDAR, it helps to start 
with a related technology— radar. In aviation, radar antennas launch pulses 
of radio or microwaves at planes to learn their locations by timing 
how long the beams take to bounce back. That’s a limited way of seeing, though, because the large beam-size 
can’t visualize fine details. In contrast, a self-driving car’s 
LIDAR system, which stands for Light Detection 
and Ranging, uses a narrow invisible infrared laser. It can image features as small as the 
button on a pedestrian’s shirt across the street. But how do we determine the shape, 
or depth, of these features? LIDAR fires a train of super-short laser 
pulses to give depth resolution. Take the moose on the country road. As the car drives by, one LIDAR pulse 
scatters off the base of its antlers, while the next may travel to the tip 
of one antler before bouncing back. Measuring how much longer 
the second pulse takes to return provides data about the antler’s shape. With a lot of short pulses, a LIDAR system
quickly renders a detailed profile. The most obvious way to create a pulse 
of light is to switch a laser on and off. But this makes a laser unstable and 
affects the precise timing of its pulses, which limits depth resolution. Better to leave it on, and use something else to periodically 
block the light reliably and rapidly. That’s where integrated photonics come in. The digital data of the internet is carried by precision-timed 
pulses of light, some as short as a hundred picoseconds. One way to create these pulses is 
with a Mach-Zehnder modulator. This device takes advantage of a 
particular wave property, called interference. Imagine dropping pebbles into a pond: as the ripples spread and overlap, 
a pattern forms. In some places, wave peaks add 
up to become very large; in other places, they completely 
cancel out. The Mach-Zehnder modulator 
does something similar. It splits waves of light along two 
parallel arms and eventually rejoins them. If the light is slowed down and 
delayed in one arm, the waves recombine out of sync and 
cancel, blocking the light. By toggling this delay in one arm, the modulator acts like an on/off switch, 
emitting pulses of light. A light pulse lasting a hundred 
picoseconds leads to a depth resolution of a 
few centimeters, but tomorrow’s cars will need 
to see better than that. By pairing the modulator with a super-
sensitive, fast-acting light detector, the resolution can be refined 
to a millimeter. That’s more than a hundred times better  than what we can make out with 
20/20 vision, from across a street. The first generation of automobile LIDAR 
has relied on complex spinning assemblies that scan from rooftops or hoods. With integrated photonics, modulators and detectors are being shrunk 
to less than a tenth of a millimeter, and packed into tiny chips that’ll one 
day fit inside a car’s lights. These chips will also include a clever 
variation on the modulator to help do away with moving parts 
and scan at rapid speeds. By slowing the light in a modulator 
arm only a tiny bit, this additional device will act more 
like a dimmer than an on/off switch. If an array of many such arms, each with 
a tiny controlled delay, is stacked in parallel, something novel 
can be designed: a steerable laser beam. From their new vantage, these smart eyes will probe and 
see more thoroughly than anything nature could’ve imagined— and help navigate any number 
of obstacles. All without anyone breaking a sweat— except for maybe one disoriented moose.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How can integrated photonics transform a LiDAR system in a self-driving car?
Options: A. toggle the speed of light in one arm, B. resolve the depth of small objects, C. shrink the device components into a chip smaller than a millimeter, D. resolve the depth of objects at great distances
Correct Option: C

Question 7: What is the benefit of pairing the Mach-Zehnder modulator with a super-sensitive, fast-acting light detector? Options: A. It reduces the power consumption of the LIDAR system, B. It increases the accuracy of the LIDAR system, C. It refines the depth resolution to a millimeter, D. It reduces the size of the LIDAR system Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the limitation of the first generation of automobile LIDAR? Options: A. It relies on complex spinning assemblies that scan from rooftops or hoods, B. It has a low depth resolution, C. It is expensive, D. It is not accurate Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the benefit of using integrated photonics in LIDAR systems? Options: A. It reduces the size of the LIDAR system, B. It increases the accuracy of the LIDAR system, C. It refines the depth resolution to a millimeter, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the potential application of the steerable laser beam technology? Options: A. It can be used to improve the accuracy of LIDAR systems, B. It can be used to reduce the size of LIDAR systems, C. It can be used to navigate obstacles in self-driving cars, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 9. 

Although the wording of the question is not identical, the intent and content of Question 9 align with the ground truth MCQ. Both questions focus on the benefits of using integrated photonics in LIDAR systems. The correct option for Question 9, "All of the above," includes the statement "It reduces the size of the LIDAR system," which is similar to the correct option for the ground truth MCQ, "shrink the device components into a chip smaller than a millimeter."

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It’s late, pitch dark, and a self-driving 
car winds down a narrow country road. Suddenly, three hazards appear 
at the same time. What happens next? Before it can navigate this 
onslaught of obstacles, the car has to detect them— gleaning enough information about 
their size, shape, and position, so that its control algorithms 
can plot the safest course. With no human at the wheel, the car needs smart eyes, sensors 
that’ll resolve these details— no matter the environment, 
weather, or how dark it is— all in a split-second. That’s a tall order, but there’s a 
solution that partners two things: a special kind of laser-based probe 
called LIDAR, and a miniature version of 
the communications technology that keeps the internet humming,
called integrated photonics. To understand LIDAR, it helps to start 
with a related technology— radar. In aviation, radar antennas launch pulses 
of radio or microwaves at planes to learn their locations by timing 
how long the beams take to bounce back. That’s a limited way of seeing, though, because the large beam-size 
can’t visualize fine details. In contrast, a self-driving car’s 
LIDAR system, which stands for Light Detection 
and Ranging, uses a narrow invisible infrared laser. It can image features as small as the 
button on a pedestrian’s shirt across the street. But how do we determine the shape, 
or depth, of these features? LIDAR fires a train of super-short laser 
pulses to give depth resolution. Take the moose on the country road. As the car drives by, one LIDAR pulse 
scatters off the base of its antlers, while the next may travel to the tip 
of one antler before bouncing back. Measuring how much longer 
the second pulse takes to return provides data about the antler’s shape. With a lot of short pulses, a LIDAR system
quickly renders a detailed profile. The most obvious way to create a pulse 
of light is to switch a laser on and off. But this makes a laser unstable and 
affects the precise timing of its pulses, which limits depth resolution. Better to leave it on, and use something else to periodically 
block the light reliably and rapidly. That’s where integrated photonics come in. The digital data of the internet is carried by precision-timed 
pulses of light, some as short as a hundred picoseconds. One way to create these pulses is 
with a Mach-Zehnder modulator. This device takes advantage of a 
particular wave property, called interference. Imagine dropping pebbles into a pond: as the ripples spread and overlap, 
a pattern forms. In some places, wave peaks add 
up to become very large; in other places, they completely 
cancel out. The Mach-Zehnder modulator 
does something similar. It splits waves of light along two 
parallel arms and eventually rejoins them. If the light is slowed down and 
delayed in one arm, the waves recombine out of sync and 
cancel, blocking the light. By toggling this delay in one arm, the modulator acts like an on/off switch, 
emitting pulses of light. A light pulse lasting a hundred 
picoseconds leads to a depth resolution of a 
few centimeters, but tomorrow’s cars will need 
to see better than that. By pairing the modulator with a super-
sensitive, fast-acting light detector, the resolution can be refined 
to a millimeter. That’s more than a hundred times better  than what we can make out with 
20/20 vision, from across a street. The first generation of automobile LIDAR 
has relied on complex spinning assemblies that scan from rooftops or hoods. With integrated photonics, modulators and detectors are being shrunk 
to less than a tenth of a millimeter, and packed into tiny chips that’ll one 
day fit inside a car’s lights. These chips will also include a clever 
variation on the modulator to help do away with moving parts 
and scan at rapid speeds. By slowing the light in a modulator 
arm only a tiny bit, this additional device will act more 
like a dimmer than an on/off switch. If an array of many such arms, each with 
a tiny controlled delay, is stacked in parallel, something novel 
can be designed: a steerable laser beam. From their new vantage, these smart eyes will probe and 
see more thoroughly than anything nature could’ve imagined— and help navigate any number 
of obstacles. All without anyone breaking a sweat— except for maybe one disoriented moose.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: On an integrated photonics chip, what does the device for steering a laser beam have in common with a Mach-Zehnder modulator?
Options: A. both devices rely on Time of Flight, B. both devices create pulses of light, C. both devices split light into multiple optical paths, repeatedly, D. both devices slow down the speed of light
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What technology is used in aviation to learn the locations of planes by timing how long the beams take to bounce back? Options: A. LIDAR, B. Radar, C. Integrated Photonics, D. Mach-Zehnder Modulator Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the primary function of LIDAR in a self-driving car? Options: A. To detect obstacles and plot the safest course, B. To provide internet connectivity, C. To visualize fine details of the surroundings, D. To measure the speed of the car Correct Option: A
Question 3: How does LIDAR determine the shape or depth of features? Options: A. By firing a single long laser pulse, B. By firing a train of super-short laser pulses, C. By using a Mach-Zehnder modulator, D. By using integrated photonics Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the limitation of switching a laser on and off to create a pulse of light? Options: A. It makes the laser unstable and affects the precise timing of its pulses, B. It reduces the depth resolution of the LIDAR system, C. It increases the power consumption of the LIDAR system, D. It reduces the accuracy of the LIDAR system Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the purpose of the Mach-Zehnder modulator in integrated photonics? Options: A. To create precision-timed pulses of light, B. To increase the power of the laser, C. To reduce the size of the LIDAR system, D. To improve the accuracy of the LIDAR system Correct Option: A
Question 6: How does the Mach-Zehnder modulator create pulses of light? Options: A. By splitting waves of light along two parallel arms and rejoining them, B. By using a laser to create pulses of light, C. By using a light detector to create pulses of light, D. By using a modulator to create pulses of light Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the benefit of pairing the Mach-Zehnder modulator with a super-sensitive, fast-acting light detector? Options: A. It reduces the power consumption of the LIDAR system, B. It increases the accuracy of the LIDAR system, C. It refines the depth resolution to a millimeter, D. It reduces the size of the LIDAR system Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the limitation of the first generation of automobile LIDAR? Options: A. It relies on complex spinning assemblies that scan from rooftops or hoods, B. It has a low depth resolution, C. It is expensive, D. It is not accurate Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the benefit of using integrated photonics in LIDAR systems? Options: A. It reduces the size of the LIDAR system, B. It increases the accuracy of the LIDAR system, C. It refines the depth resolution to a millimeter, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is the potential application of the steerable laser beam technology? Options: A. It can be used to improve the accuracy of LIDAR systems, B. It can be used to reduce the size of LIDAR systems, C. It can be used to navigate obstacles in self-driving cars, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

Although this question does not directly ask about the similarity between the device for steering a laser beam and the Mach-Zehnder modulator, it does relate to the Mach-Zehnder modulator, which is mentioned in the correct option of the ground truth MCQ. However, a more suitable match is not available among the generated MCQs.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What shape are your cells? Squishy cylinders? Jagged zig-zags? You probably don’t think much about
the bodies of these building blocks, but at the microscopic level, small 
changes can have huge consequences. And while some adaptations change 
these shapes for the better, others can spark a cascade of 
debilitating complications. This is the story of sickle-cell disease. Sickle-cell disease affects the 
red blood cells, which transport oxygen from the lungs 
to all the tissues in the body. To perform this vital task, red blood cells are filled with hemoglobin
proteins to carry oxygen molecules. These proteins float independently inside the red blood cell’s pliable, 
doughnut-like shape, keeping the cells flexible enough to accommodate even the 
tiniest of blood vessels. But in sickle cell disease, a single genetic mutation alters
the structure of hemoglobin. After releasing oxygen to tissues, these mutated proteins lock 
together into rigid rows. Rods of hemoglobin cause the cell 
to deform into a long, pointed sickle. These red blood cells are 
harder and stickier, and no longer flow smoothly through 
blood vessels. Sickled cells snag and pile up– sometimes blocking the vessel completely. This keeps oxygen from reaching
a variety of cells, causing the wide range of symptoms experienced by people 
with sickle-cell disease. Starting when they’re 
less than a year old, patients suffer from repeated episodes of
stabbing pain in oxygen-starved tissues. The location of the clogged vessel determines the specific 
symptoms experienced. A blockage in the spleen, 
part of the immune system, puts patients at risk for 
dangerous infections. A pileup in the lungs can produce 
fevers and difficulty breathing. A clog near the eye can cause vision 
problems and retinal detachment. And if the obstructed vessels 
supply the brain the patient could even 
suffer a stroke. Worse still, sickled red blood cells 
also don’t survive very long— just 10 or 20 days, versus a 
healthy cell’s 4 months. This short lifespan means that patients live with a constantly
depleted supply of red blood cells; a condition called sickle-cell anemia. Perhaps what’s most surprising 
about this malignant mutation is that it originally evolved
as a beneficial adaptation. Researchers have been able to trace
the origins of the sickle cell mutation to regions historically ravaged 
by a tropical disease called malaria. Spread by a parasite found 
in local mosquitoes, malaria uses red blood cells as incubators to spread quickly and lethally 
through the bloodstream. However, the same structural changes
that turn red blood cells into roadblocks also make them more resistant to malaria. And if a child inherits a copy of the
mutation from only one parent, there will be just enough abnormal 
hemoglobin to make life difficult for the 
malaria parasite, while most of their red blood cells retain
their normal shape and function. In regions rife with this parasite, sickle cell mutation offered a serious 
evolutionary advantage. But as the adaptation flourished, it became clear that inheriting the 
mutation from both parents resulted in sickle-cell anemia. Today, most people with 
sickle-cell disease can trace their ancestry to a country
where malaria is endemic. And this mutation still plays a key role
in Africa, where more than 90% of malaria 
infections occur worldwide. Fortunately, as this “adaptation” thrives, our treatment for sickle cell continues 
to improve. For years, hydroxyurea was the only 
medication available to reduce the amount of sickling, blunting symptoms and 
increasing life expectancy. Bone marrow transplantations 
offer a curative measure, but these procedures are 
complicated and often inaccessible. But promising new medications 
are intervening in novel ways, like keeping oxygen bonded to 
hemoglobin to prevent sickling, or reducing the stickiness 
of sickled cells. And the ability to edit DNA has raised the possibility of enabling 
stem cells to produce normal hemoglobin. As these tools become available in the areas most affected by malaria
and sickle cell disease, we can improve the quality of life for more patients with this 
adverse adaptation.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What shape should your red blood cell be?
Options: A. A Banana, B. A Donut, C. A Sphere, D. A Teardrop
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary function of red blood cells in the human body? Options: A. To fight off infections, B. To transport oxygen from the lungs to tissues, C. To regulate body temperature, D. To produce hemoglobin proteins Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the shape of a normal red blood cell? Options: A. Squishy cylinder, B. Jagged zig-zag, C. Pliable, doughnut-like shape, D. Long, pointed sickle Correct Option: C
Question 3: What happens to the hemoglobin proteins in red blood cells affected by sickle cell disease after releasing oxygen to tissues? Options: A. They break down and disappear, B. They lock together into rigid rows, C. They become more flexible, D. They start producing more oxygen Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the result of sickled red blood cells piling up and blocking a blood vessel? Options: A. Increased oxygen flow to tissues, B. Reduced risk of infections, C. Oxygen deprivation to tissues, leading to various symptoms, D. Improved blood circulation Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the average lifespan of a sickled red blood cell compared to a healthy one? Options: A. 4 months vs. 10-20 days, B. 10-20 days vs. 4 months, C. 1 year vs. 6 months, D. 6 months vs. 1 year Correct Option: B
Question 6: Why did the sickle cell mutation originally evolve as a beneficial adaptation? Options: A. To fight off cancer cells, B. To improve blood circulation, C. To make red blood cells more resistant to malaria, D. To increase oxygen production Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the name of the medication that has been used for years to reduce the amount of sickling and blunt symptoms of sickle cell disease? Options: A. Hydroxyurea, B. Sickle-cell-x, C. Malaria-b-gone, D. Hemoglobin- helper Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is a potential new approach to treating sickle cell disease using DNA editing technology? Options: A. Enabling stem cells to produce abnormal hemoglobin, B. Reducing the stickiness of sickled cells, C. Keeping oxygen bonded to hemoglobin to prevent sickling, D. Enabling stem cells to produce normal hemoglobin Correct Option: D
Question 9: If a child inherits a copy of the sickle cell mutation from only one parent, what is the likely outcome? Options: A. They will develop sickle-cell anemia, B. They will have a reduced risk of malaria, C. They will have a mix of normal and abnormal hemoglobin, making life difficult for the malaria parasite, D. They will have no symptoms of sickle cell disease Correct Option: C
Question 10: According to the transcript, where do more than 90% of malaria infections occur worldwide? Options: A. Africa, B. Asia, C. Europe, D. South America Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (asking about the shape of a normal red blood cell), options (providing various shapes as possible answers), and content (focusing on the shape of red blood cells). The correct option in Question 2, "Pliable, doughnut-like shape," is also similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ, "A Donut." 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 2.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 4

Question 5: What is the average lifespan of a sickled red blood cell compared to a healthy one? Options: A. 4 months vs. 10-20 days, B. 10-20 days vs. 4 months, C. 1 year vs. 6 months, D. 6 months vs. 1 year Correct Option: B
Question 6: Why did the sickle cell mutation originally evolve as a beneficial adaptation? Options: A. To fight off cancer cells, B. To improve blood circulation, C. To make red blood cells more resistant to malaria, D. To increase oxygen production Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the name of the medication that has been used for years to reduce the amount of sickling and blunt symptoms of sickle cell disease? Options: A. Hydroxyurea, B. Sickle-cell-x, C. Malaria-b-gone, D. Hemoglobin- helper Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is a potential new approach to treating sickle cell disease using DNA editing technology? Options: A. Enabling stem cells to produce abnormal hemoglobin, B. Reducing the stickiness of sickled cells, C. Keeping oxygen bonded to hemoglobin to prevent sickling, D. Enabling stem cells to produce normal hemoglobin Correct Option: D
Question 9: If a child inherits a copy of the sickle cell mutation from only one parent, what is the likely outcome? Options: A. They will develop sickle-cell anemia, B. They will have a reduced risk of malaria, C. They will have a mix of normal and abnormal hemoglobin, making life difficult for the malaria parasite, D. They will have no symptoms of sickle cell disease Correct Option: C
Question 10: According to the transcript, where do more than 90% of malaria infections occur worldwide? Options: A. Africa, B. Asia, C. Europe, D. South America Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (asking about the shape of red blood cells) and options (providing various shapes as possible answers). Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What shape are your cells? Squishy cylinders? Jagged zig-zags? You probably don’t think much about
the bodies of these building blocks, but at the microscopic level, small 
changes can have huge consequences. And while some adaptations change 
these shapes for the better, others can spark a cascade of 
debilitating complications. This is the story of sickle-cell disease. Sickle-cell disease affects the 
red blood cells, which transport oxygen from the lungs 
to all the tissues in the body. To perform this vital task, red blood cells are filled with hemoglobin
proteins to carry oxygen molecules. These proteins float independently inside the red blood cell’s pliable, 
doughnut-like shape, keeping the cells flexible enough to accommodate even the 
tiniest of blood vessels. But in sickle cell disease, a single genetic mutation alters
the structure of hemoglobin. After releasing oxygen to tissues, these mutated proteins lock 
together into rigid rows. Rods of hemoglobin cause the cell 
to deform into a long, pointed sickle. These red blood cells are 
harder and stickier, and no longer flow smoothly through 
blood vessels. Sickled cells snag and pile up– sometimes blocking the vessel completely. This keeps oxygen from reaching
a variety of cells, causing the wide range of symptoms experienced by people 
with sickle-cell disease. Starting when they’re 
less than a year old, patients suffer from repeated episodes of
stabbing pain in oxygen-starved tissues. The location of the clogged vessel determines the specific 
symptoms experienced. A blockage in the spleen, 
part of the immune system, puts patients at risk for 
dangerous infections. A pileup in the lungs can produce 
fevers and difficulty breathing. A clog near the eye can cause vision 
problems and retinal detachment. And if the obstructed vessels 
supply the brain the patient could even 
suffer a stroke. Worse still, sickled red blood cells 
also don’t survive very long— just 10 or 20 days, versus a 
healthy cell’s 4 months. This short lifespan means that patients live with a constantly
depleted supply of red blood cells; a condition called sickle-cell anemia. Perhaps what’s most surprising 
about this malignant mutation is that it originally evolved
as a beneficial adaptation. Researchers have been able to trace
the origins of the sickle cell mutation to regions historically ravaged 
by a tropical disease called malaria. Spread by a parasite found 
in local mosquitoes, malaria uses red blood cells as incubators to spread quickly and lethally 
through the bloodstream. However, the same structural changes
that turn red blood cells into roadblocks also make them more resistant to malaria. And if a child inherits a copy of the
mutation from only one parent, there will be just enough abnormal 
hemoglobin to make life difficult for the 
malaria parasite, while most of their red blood cells retain
their normal shape and function. In regions rife with this parasite, sickle cell mutation offered a serious 
evolutionary advantage. But as the adaptation flourished, it became clear that inheriting the 
mutation from both parents resulted in sickle-cell anemia. Today, most people with 
sickle-cell disease can trace their ancestry to a country
where malaria is endemic. And this mutation still plays a key role
in Africa, where more than 90% of malaria 
infections occur worldwide. Fortunately, as this “adaptation” thrives, our treatment for sickle cell continues 
to improve. For years, hydroxyurea was the only 
medication available to reduce the amount of sickling, blunting symptoms and 
increasing life expectancy. Bone marrow transplantations 
offer a curative measure, but these procedures are 
complicated and often inaccessible. But promising new medications 
are intervening in novel ways, like keeping oxygen bonded to 
hemoglobin to prevent sickling, or reducing the stickiness 
of sickled cells. And the ability to edit DNA has raised the possibility of enabling 
stem cells to produce normal hemoglobin. As these tools become available in the areas most affected by malaria
and sickle cell disease, we can improve the quality of life for more patients with this 
adverse adaptation.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What complication can a patient with sickle cell anemia have if the blood flow in the brain is blocked?
Options: A. Meningitis, B. Pneumonia, C. Retinal detachment, D. Stroke
Correct Option: D

Question 3: What happens to the hemoglobin proteins in red blood cells affected by sickle cell disease after releasing oxygen to tissues? Options: A. They break down and disappear, B. They lock together into rigid rows, C. They become more flexible, D. They start producing more oxygen Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the result of sickled red blood cells piling up and blocking a blood vessel? Options: A. Increased oxygen flow to tissues, B. Reduced risk of infections, C. Oxygen deprivation to tissues, leading to various symptoms, D. Improved blood circulation Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the average lifespan of a sickled red blood cell compared to a healthy one? Options: A. 4 months vs. 10-20 days, B. 10-20 days vs. 4 months, C. 1 year vs. 6 months, D. 6 months vs. 1 year Correct Option: B
Question 6: Why did the sickle cell mutation originally evolve as a beneficial adaptation? Options: A. To fight off cancer cells, B. To improve blood circulation, C. To make red blood cells more resistant to malaria, D. To increase oxygen production Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the name of the medication that has been used for years to reduce the amount of sickling and blunt symptoms of sickle cell disease? Options: A. Hydroxyurea, B. Sickle-cell-x, C. Malaria-b-gone, D. Hemoglobin- helper Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is a potential new approach to treating sickle cell disease using DNA editing technology? Options: A. Enabling stem cells to produce abnormal hemoglobin, B. Reducing the stickiness of sickled cells, C. Keeping oxygen bonded to hemoglobin to prevent sickling, D. Enabling stem cells to produce normal hemoglobin Correct Option: D
Question 9: If a child inherits a copy of the sickle cell mutation from only one parent, what is the likely outcome? Options: A. They will develop sickle-cell anemia, B. They will have a reduced risk of malaria, C. They will have a mix of normal and abnormal hemoglobin, making life difficult for the malaria parasite, D. They will have no symptoms of sickle cell disease Correct Option: C
Question 10: According to the transcript, where do more than 90% of malaria infections occur worldwide? Options: A. Africa, B. Asia, C. Europe, D. South America Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.

and sickle cell disease, we can improve the quality of life for more patients with this 
adverse adaptation.
